entry.et: Middle English, probably from enclos enclosed, from Anglo-French, past participle of enclore to enclose, from Vulgar Latin *inclaudere, alteration of Latin includere include

def.dt: :to close in :surround enclose a porch with glass
:to fence off (common land) for individual use
:to include along with something else in a parcel or envelope a check is enclosed herewith
